key_work.title: Théâtre Optique
key_work.brief_description: In 1892, two years after developing the praxinoscope theatre, Charles-Émile Reynaud debuted his grandest invention – the Théâtre Optique – in Paris. This device projected moving pictures that had been hand-painted onto flexible, coloured, regularly perforated strips of gelatine crystalloid.

start.title: Nine to Five
start.brief_description: 9 to 5 is an office satire about three female secretaries who decide to get revenge on their tyrannical, sexist boss by abducting him and running the business themselves. Features star turns by Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dolly Parton.

end.title: Workout
end.brief_description: Jane Fonda’s Workout is the original VHS workout program. The program includes a 30 minute beginners’ class and a 60 minute advanced session. Fond would go on to release 23 different home workout videos and sell more than 17 million copies.

links.description: Jane Fonda not only co-starred in 9 to 5 but originated and steered the project through her production company IPC Films. Two years later, the first of her Jane Fonda’s Workout videos sold more than a million copies on the relatively new home VHS format.

start.title: Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory
start.creator_credit: Auguste Lumière, Louis Lumière and Lumière
start.brief_description: The film La Sortie des Usines Lumière à Lyon (Workers Leaving the Lumière Factory in Lyon, 1895) by the Lumière brothers is 45 seconds long and is considered one of the first motion pictures ever made.

end.title: Workers Leaving the Factory

end.brief_description: In this documentary essay based on the Lumière brothers groundbreaking film, Harun Farocki uses to provide an insight into the changes both in work and film through motion pictures of workers leaving factories across the years.

links.description: One hundred years after the Lumière brothers’ first film, German artist Harun Farocki revisited its themes in Arbeiter verlassen die Fabrik, expanding the Lumière’s 45-second home movie into a 37-minute cinematic essay on politics and industrial power.

end.title: Jesus
end.creator_credit: John Krish, John Heyman and Richard Dalton
end.brief_description: A 1979 biblical drama film directed by Peter Sykes and John Krish; Jesus primarily uses the Gospel of Luke as the main basis for the story. A voice-over narration is featured sporadically throughout the film, providing background information on characters and events.

links.description: The 1979 film Jesus lost $2 million on its cinema release. But thanks to the same VHS technology exploited by Jane Fonda it was distributed internationally in more than 1,000 languages and has been watched by an estimated 3 billion people.

links.description: In 1888, Charles-Émile Reynaud patented the Théâtre Optique, which featured film perforation and sprocket technology. The Lumière brothers had studied Reynaud’s invention and in 1895, patented their “cinematographe”, an early camera-projector that advanced this technology, and produced La Sortie de l’Usine Lumière à Lyon.
